answers.author: Pam Broviak
answers.text:
I have seen cities handle this several ways - The two extremes are that the city annexes the property regardless of the condition or availability of infrastructure.  (This might occur because the city needs to annex undeveloped property to reach another parcel where a development is proposed or where a special district will be created.) And at the other extreme, some cities will not annex any property without all of the infrastructure being brought up to their standards or without having it in place. There are several scenarios in the middle with the city and property owner sharing in the development costs. From what I have seen, the approach chosen is highly dependent on the goals of the city regarding that specific annexation - do they really want or need the property or will annexation primarily only benefit the property owner?

author: Shannon Gerard
text: Has any city annexed a property or been approached to annex a subdivision with failing infrastructure? And if so, how was it handled? Was the subdivision required to correct any issues prior to annexation or did the City take on the responsibility of correcting the issues? Does anyone have a policy, ordinance, resolution out there that they can forward to me?
title: Annexation Question
